assignments.name: Lesson 1 EP (Extra Credit)
assignments.description:
Extra Credit (up to 4%)

Students may earn extra credit by completing the Lesson Extra Practice (EP) via McGraw-Hill Connect for each Lesson. There are 12 EP (Extra Credit) opportunities, one for each of the 12 Lessons of the course. Each EP (Extra Credit) allows you to earn up to 0.33% extra credit toward your final course grade. You may take each EP (Extra Credit) an unlimited number of times, and the highest score will be used toward the Extra Credit (for example: if your highest score on an EP assignment for the Lesson is 90%, you would earn 90% of .33, or .297, in Extra Credit toward your final grade).

All of the EP (Extra Credit) for a Module will stay open until 11:59 p.m. on the night before the scheduled exam (see the Course Calendar for specific dates/times). The EP (Extra Credit) is designed to be attempted/taken at the completion of each Lesson. You may also take them again in the days before an Exam for study purposes; however, please do not wait until the last days before an exam to attempt all of the EP (Extra Credit) for the first time for the entire Module. If you do, you may find there is not enough time to complete them and/or fully understand the Lesson material.

Once the EP (Extra Credit) close, it cannot be re-opened for any reason, and there will be no further Extra Credit opportunities for that Module. Likewise, extensions will not be granted for EP (Extra Credit) for any reason, including technical issues, personal extenuating circumstances, or illness. Plan ahead and complete at least one attempt at each EP (Extra Credit) at the end of each Lesson throughout your study of the material, so you do not lose your Extra Credit opportunity due to an emergency at the end of the Module.

You may take each EP (Extra Credit) an unlimited number of times, and the highest score will be used toward the Extra Credit (for example: if your highest score on an EP assignment for the Lesson is 90%, you would earn 90% of .33, or .297, in Extra Credit toward your final grade).

All of the EP (Extra Credit) for a Module will stay open until 11:59 p.m. on the night before the scheduled exam (see the Course Calendar for specific dates/times). The EP (Extra Credit) is designed to be attempted/taken at the completion of each Lesson. You may also take them again in the days before an Exam for study purposes; however, please do not wait until the last days before an exam to attempt all of the EP (Extra Credit) for the first time for the entire Module. If you do, you may find there is not enough time to complete them and/or fully understand the Lesson material.

Once the EP (Extra Credit) close, it cannot be re-opened for any reason, and there will be no further Extra Credit opportunities for that Module. Likewise, extensions will not be granted for EP (Extra Credit) for any reason, including technical issues, personal extenuating circumstances, or illness. Plan ahead and complete at least one attempt at each EP (Extra Credit) at the end of each Lesson throughout your study of the material, so you do not lose your Extra Credit opportunity due to an emergency at the end of the Module.

assignments.name: Exam_1_ACCTG211_SP25 - Requires Respondus LockDown Browser
assignments.description:
Following is the Smeal College of Business Honor Code:

We, the Smeal College of Business community, aspire to the highest ethical standards and will hold each other accountable to them. We will not engage in any action that is improper or that creates the appearance of impropriety in our academic lives, and we intend to hold this standard in our future careers.

 

According to the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct:

Academic integrity is a basic guiding principle for all academic activity at Penn State University, allowing the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest, and responsible manner. According to the University’s Code of Conduct, you must neither engage in nor tolerate academic dishonesty. This includes, but is not limited to cheating, plagiarism, fabrication of information or citations, facilitating acts of academic dishonesty by others, unauthorized possession of examinations, submitting work of another person, or work previously used in another course without informing the instructor, or tampering with the academic work of other students.

The disciplinary process and your rights regarding academic integrity are outlined in Penn State’s University Faculty Senate Policy 49-20 and are supplemented by Penn State’s Office of Undergraduate Education Procedure G-9.

While this is not an exhaustive list, following are a few examples of actions during the examination process that could result in an Honor Code violation: 1) accessing items that you have been asked to place in the Testing Center’s approved green-colored drawstring bags; 2) accessing an unapproved examination aid; 3) using a calculator other than the calculator provided to you during the exam check-in process; 4) reproducing exam questions for other parties or transmitting exam questions to other parties; 5) entering the testing center restroom facility with your cell phone, scratch paper, exam ticket, or any unapproved examination aid; and 6) leaving the Testing Center with your scratch paper or exam ticket.

By clicking on the "Take the Quiz" button below, you implicitly certify that you have not engaged in any action that conflicts with the Smeal College of Business Honor Code or the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct prior to the start of the exam, and you further implicitly certify that you will abide by the Smeal College of Business Honor Code and the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct during the exam.

Copyright 2022 Schalyn Sohn and Kristy Schenck.  No portion of this exam may be used for commercial purposes, reproduced, published, broadcast, rewritten for broadcast or publication, or redistributed directly or indirectly in any medium without the express written permission of the authors.

assignments.name: PS5
assignments.description:
Solve the following from the computer organization zybook: (50 %)

  • Participation and challenging activities from 3.1 - 3.5.

Please submit your responses in the form of a PDF document to the following questions. (50 %)

1-Advancements in FPGA technology have enabled improved computational capabilities at lower costs. What are the implications of these advancements and how could they benefit society? (This is an open-ended question that encourages discussion. It may require you to conduct research through various means such as the internet, library resources, and more to gather the necessary information and formulate your response).

2-In our class discussion, we talked about the historical progression of computing systems. What about the environmental and social implications of the trajectory it’s on. Additionally, think about some potential future developments that could come out of it and discuss an application that could be built which we don’t yet see. Explain what the implications of that are in more detail. (250-word minimum)

assignments.name: EECS Academic Integrity Quiz
assignments.description:
This quiz is to help you check your understanding of ethical practices in engineering and what constitutes an academic integrity violation in the School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. The quiz contains some basic multiple-choice and T/F questions about academic integrity policy, as well as scenarios in which you will be asked to determine whether the action described would be considered an AI violation.

NOTE: A score of 100% is required to pass the quiz and complete the module, which will unlock other content in the course. If you do not pass, go back and review the material in the module. You may retake the quiz as many times as necessary.
